title: NASA's Hubble Telescope discovers a rogue 'Magnetar' racing through deep space
summary: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has detected SGR 0501+4516, a magnetar speeding through our galaxy. Unlike typical neutron stars, this supermagnetic object's origin remains mysterious as it doesn't align with any known supernova remnant. Scientists speculate it may have formed from a neutron star merger or white dwarf collapse.
content:
NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has spotted a magnetar, a supermagnetic neutron star speeding across our galaxy. Its name? SGR 0501+4516. However, where it came from is still a mystery. Scientists say it might not have formed in a supernova like most neutron stars.

A magnetar is a type of neutron star with a magnetic field that is trillion times stronger than Earth's. If one passes near Earth, it could wipe out every credit card on our planet. If you get within 600 miles, it would tear our atoms apart. Only 30 magnetars have been discovered in our Milky Way so far.

First discovered in 2008 by NASA's Swift Observatory, SGR 0501 was seen flashing powerful gamma rays from the Milky Way's edge. It was believed to be born near a supernova remnant (HB9). However the new data tells a different story.

Using images from 2010, 2012, and 2020, scientists tracked its tiny motion across space. They used data from ESA's Gaia spacecraft for precise star maps. The magnetar's path doesn't line up with HB9 or any known supernova.

Scientists believe SGR 0501+4516 might've formed from the merger of two neutron stars or an accretion induced collapse when a white dwarf star pulls in too much gas and collapses. This could explain its formation without a supernova explosion.

SGR 0501 might help solve the mystery of Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs), intense, short blasts of radio waves. Hubble has more observations planned to study other magnetars in our galaxy, which could reveal their formation process and impact on high-energy events.
